CommonFields.Title: Mechanical properties of Al2O3/polymethylmethacrylate nanocomposites
CommonFields.Author: Ash, Benjamin J.
Rogers, Diana F.
Wiegand, Christopher J.
Schadler, Linda S.
Siegel, Richard W.
Benicewicz, Brian C.
Apple, Tom
CommonFields.Publisher: Wiley Subscription Services, Inc., A Wiley Company
CommonFields.Location: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Rensselaer Nanotechnology Center, Troy, NY 12180‐3590, USA

Mixing.Description: Twenty grams of nanoparticles were suspended in ethanol through 10 minutes of sonication (VCX-400 Sonics Materials Vibracell) at 70% power. The power setting refers to the percentage of maximum sonic power (400 watts) that is directed into the sample.

The resulting slurry was centrifuged for 3 minutes at 3000 rpm to remove particles larger than 100 nm. This procedure was used to achieve a narrower particle size distribution than is available from the supplier.

Additive.Description: The silane coupling agent was added to a 95/5 mixture of ethanol and water adjusted to a pH of 4.5 by addition of acetic acid.

Mixing.Description: This solution was reacted at room temperature for 10 minutes for silanol formation.
The silanol solution was then dropped into the ethanol/nanoparticle sluny at a rate of approximately 20 ml/min while sonicating the mixture at 70% power.

Drying-Evaporation.Description: The slurry was then evaporated at reduced pressure for 2 hours at 60°C to remove the solvent.

Heating.Description: The particles were cured under vacuum at 60°C for a period of 24 hours.

Mixing.Description: Coated or uncoated nanoparticles were added to MMA monomer and dispersed via sonication at 70% power for 10 minutes. During the last two minutes of the sonication, the initiator (AIBN) and chain transfer agent (1 - decanethiol) were added.
The polymerization was carried out at 55°C under a nitrogen blanket for 21 hours with two additional sonication steps of 40% power at the 1 and 2 hour points.

Drying-Evaporation.Description: The polymer was then broken into small pieces and dried in a vacuum oven for 2 hours at 115°C to drive off water and residual monomer.

Heating.Description: The resulting nanocomposite was compression molded into tensile specimens (AS" D638-95 Qpe IV) in a hydraulic press (Carver 12 Ton) at 180°C and 2.5 mTons.
Specimens were allowed to cool to room temperature under pressure for a period of 6 hours and, after removal, were sanded (400 grit) to remove flashing.

Transmission_Electron_Microscopy.Description: The speed and duration requirements were chosen by observing the gross distribution of remaining particles through transmission electron microscope (TEM) measurements.

Dynamic_Mechanical_Analysis.Description: Dynamic mechanical thermal analysis (DMTA) was carried out on a Rheometric Scientific DMTA V using single cantilever bending mode at 1 Hz with 0.1% strain. Temperature ramps from 15°C to 200°C at 2°C mix1 were conducted to determine the Tg of the materials.

Differential_Scanning_Calorimetry.Description: In specific cases, Tg was also obtained through differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Seiko Instruments SSC5200) with a temperature ramp from 25°C to 190°C at 10°C per min.

Nuclear_Magnetic_Resonance.Description: 7.5 mm coil and a quadrupolar echo sequence. An echo delay of 25 ps was used and the 90" pulse width was 3 ps. Eight scans were acquired for each spectrum with a pulse delay of 5 s.

Thermal.MeasurementMethod: Dynamic Mechanical Thermal Analysis (DMTA) in Single Cantilever Bending at 1 Hz, 0.1% Strain, and 2°C per min and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) at 10°C per min.

ImageFile.Description: typical nano-alumina particle dispersion-morphology from nanophase technology corporation
